Title: Reform UK will not run for York and North Yorkshire mayor
Author: By Adam Laver
Content:
Reform UK has confirmed that it will not field a candidate in Mayâ€™s York and North Yorkshireâ€™s mayoral election.
Despite committing to running in every constituency in the upcoming general election, Reform UK told the Local Democracy Reporting Service it wonâ€™t compete to have the first metro mayor of York and North Yorkshire.
VotersÂ will elect a mayor on May 2 to oversee a new combined authority with devolved power over housing, education and transport.
Reform UK, which was founded by former UKIP leader Nigel Farage, did not respond when asked to comment further on not selecting a candidate.
Although Reform UKâ€™s presence in the general electionÂ could cost the Conservatives seatsÂ in the House of Commons, low turnout in local elections may mean this wouldnâ€™t make a difference anyway.
Keane Duncan, the Conservative candidate for the mayoral election, was also approached to comment on whether he thought the lack of a Reform UK candidate could affect his chances, but did not respond.
Dr Richard Hayton, associate professor of politics at the University of Leeds, said: â€œThe Conservatives might hope that the absence of a Reform UK candidate in the York and North Yorkshire mayoral election will boost Keane Duncanâ€™s chances of victory, but it is likely to have only a marginal impact on the result.
â€œTurnout in such ballots is not usually high, so any voters keen to back Reform UK as a way of sending a message to either of the two main parties are likely to stay away rather than return to the fold.â€
Only the Conservatives, Labour and the Green Party have announced candidates for the mayoral election, as well as Keith Tordoff who is running as an independent.
The Liberal Democrats hope to announce a candidate â€œshortlyâ€ and The Yorkshire Party is yet to replace Mr Tordoff who was previously its candidate.
The deadline for parties to submit candidates by is April 5.
Reform UK has not neglected all of the combined authority elections, however, andÂ has announced candidates forÂ North East mayorÂ andÂ London mayor.
The right-wing party also has an agreement with the Social Democratic Party and will endorse its candidate David Bettney for the South Yorkshire mayoral election.
Polling for the general election, which is likely to take place in the second half of 2024, suggestsÂ support for Reform UK nationally is around 12 per cent.
UKIP, Nigel Farageâ€™s former party, received 12.6 per cent of the voteshare in the 2015 general election, winning almost four million votes and one seat in House of Commons.
Robert Ford, a professor of political science at the University of Manchester, told The Guardian that Reform UK â€œharms the Conservatives more now than UKIP did in 2015 because the post-Brexit Tories have a lot more â€˜Ukippyâ€™ voters, who they picked up in 2017 and 2019.â€
Reform UK was known as the Brexit Party during the 2019 general election, but did not stand against sitting Conservative MPs.
â€œNew Reform UK candidates will therefore offer an option to voters in those seats that wasnâ€™t there in 2019,â€ Mr Ford said.

Title: Irish deputy premier says â€˜no excuse for delayâ€™ in aid to Gaza
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
Irelandâ€™s deputy premier has said he will be telling EU foreign affairs leaders â€œthere is no excuseâ€ for delays in getting humanitarian aid into Gaza.
Tanaiste Micheal Martin said Mondayâ€™s Foreign Affairs Council summit in Brussels will be â€œintensiveâ€, with about six hours set aside to discuss the Middle East, after which they will speak about the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
The 27 European Union foreign ministers are also meeting their counterparts from Israel, the Palestinian Authority, Ukraine, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Jordan as well as the secretary-general of the League of Arab States.
Mr Martin, who is also Irelandâ€™s foreign affairs and defence minister, said he will be looking to see if the EU can put pressure on Israel to stop its actions in Gaza.
Looking forward to intensive meetings on the Middle East and Ukraine at todayâ€™s #FAC.
I will reiterate our call for a ceasefire in Gaza and unimpeded access of humanitarian aid.
The situation is dire â€“ there is no excuse now for any delays in getting vital aid into Gaza. pic.twitter.com/QTG68vwlzq
â€” MicheÃ¡l Martin (@MichealMartinTD) January 22, 2024
It comes after he said at the weekend that Ireland will be assessing the legal case by South Africa accusing Israel of genocide at the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
Mr Martin said Ireland will review the case being presented and decide whether to join once the preliminary stages â€“ which call for interim measures such as a ceasefire â€“ have concluded.
At the weekend local health authorities reported that 25,000 Palestinians have been killed since the start of the Israeli operation, launched after Hamasâ€™s attack on October 7 in which 1,200 Israelis were killed.
Mr Martin is to state Irelandâ€™s â€œprofound concernâ€ about the danger faced by people in Gaza and reiterate Irelandâ€™s call for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire.
Speaking on his way into the meeting, Mr Martin said: â€œFrom Irelandâ€™s perspective, we will be again putting a lot of pressure on and calling for a ceasefire in Gaza, and also absolute, unimpeded access for humanitarian aid.
â€œThe reports we are receiving, even as late as last evening, are dire in respect of whatâ€™s happening in Gaza, in terms of starvation, in terms of the humanitarian consequences of this war.
â€œAnd there is no excuse now for any tardiness or for any delays in respect of getting vital aid into Gaza and weâ€™ll be making those points very strongly.â€
Mr Martin also called for â€œthe unconditional release of all hostages that are held by Hamas, equally unacceptable and intolerableâ€.
He said that, while there is agreement on sanctions against Hamas at EU level, there is no agreement on sanctions against violent settlers in the West Bank, as â€œone or two countries are still holding outâ€.
On Ukraine, Mr Martin said: â€œWe have seen reprehensible attacks in Ukraine over the new year period, which has caused civilian death and significant damage to civilian infrastructure on a large scale.
â€œThese attacks show that Russia is intent on continued escalation.
â€œWhile we were able to deliver some important messages in December, including the historic decision by the European Council to open accession negotiations with Ukraine, it is clear that much work remains to be done.
â€œThere are a number of important meetings in weeks ahead, including the Foreign Affairs Council today, and it is critical that we as the EU continue to send a clear and united message of support for Ukraine.â€
Meanwhile Dana Erlich, Israelâ€™s ambassador to Ireland, has said there is an â€œunconscious biasâ€ against Israel among the Irish people.
Ms Erlich said she does not see Ireland as anti-Israel, but said there is limited publicity about Hamas and what â€œHamas is doingâ€.
Asked whether she thinks Ireland is anti-Israel, Ms Erlich said: â€œI understand that sometimes we have our differences. Obviously, we see things very differently. I donâ€™t think that Ireland is anti-Israel.
â€œBut I do feel that sometimes, maybe, there is an unconscious bias against Israel right now.
â€œIâ€™m still here only for five months so Iâ€™m learning about the country and its people. But what I see is, even recording about the war, I donâ€™t hear a lot of responsibility of what Hamas is doing.
â€œYou can be pro-Palestinian and worry for Palestiniansâ€™ life, but youâ€™re not helping them by not talking about the atrocities of Hamas is doing to their own population.â€
She told RTEâ€™s Today with Claire Byrne: â€œThe Palestinians need to be able to control themselves, but they canâ€™t have the opportunity to threaten Israel.
â€œWe donâ€™t want to stay in Gaza, we donâ€™t want to have control over Gaza, but any future solution needs to address the security of Israel.
â€œWe will not compromise on that. And throughout history, weâ€™ve shown that we are willing to make huge compromises and weâ€™ve shown that we believe in peace and we need to do that for the safety of our children.
â€œBut we will not forfeit and we will not do that on the expense of our security.â€

Title: Alabama set for first execution with nitrogen gas
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
Alabama, unless blocked by the Supreme Court, will attempt to put an inmate to death with nitrogen gas on Thursday night, a never-before-used execution method that the state claims will be humane but critics call cruel and experimental.
Kenneth Eugene Smith, a 58-year-old convicted killer whose 2022 lethal injection was called off at the last minute because authorities could not connect an IV line, is scheduled to be executed at an Alabama prison.
Alabama plans to put an industrial-type respirator mask over Smithâ€™s face and replace his breathing air with pure nitrogen gas, causing him to die from lack of oxygen.
The execution will be the first attempt to use a new execution method since the 1982 introduction of lethal injection, now the most common execution method in the United States.
Attorneys for Smith have waged a legal battle to halt the execution, arguing that the state is seeking to make Smith the â€œtest caseâ€ for the new execution method, which merits more legal scrutiny before it is used on an inmate.
â€œItâ€™s an experiment,â€ said the Rev Jeff Hood, Smithâ€™s spiritual advisor and a death penalty opponent.
Smithâ€™s lawyers asked the US Supreme Court to halt the execution on Thursday to review claims that the new method violates the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment and deserves more legal scrutiny before it is used on a person.
They said: â€œThere is little research regarding death by nitrogen hypoxia.
â€œWhen the State is considering using a novel form of execution that has never been attempted anywhere, the public has an interest in ensuring the State has researched the method adequately and established procedures to minimise the pain and suffering of the condemned person.â€
On Wednesday, justices rejected Smithâ€™s argument that it would be unconstitutional to make another attempt to execute him after the failed lethal injection.
Smith is one of two men convicted in the 1988 murder-for-hire slaying of Elizabeth Sennett.
Prosecutors said he and the other man were each paid 1,000 dollars to kill Sennett on behalf of her pastor husband, who was deeply in debt and wanted to collect on insurance.
Alabama plans to strap Smith to a gurney in the execution chamber â€” the same chamber where he was strapped down for several hours during the lethal injection attempt â€” and place a â€œfull facepiece supplied air respiratorâ€ over his face.
After he is given a chance to make a final statement, the warden, from another room, will activate the nitrogen gas.
The nitrogen will be administered through the mask for at least 15 minutes or â€œfive minutes following a flatline indication on the EKG, whichever is longer,â€ according to the state protocol.
Some states are looking for new ways to execute inmates because the drugs used in lethal injections, the most common execution method in the United States, are increasingly difficult to find.
Three states â€” Alabama, Mississippi and Oklahoma â€” have authorised nitrogen hypoxia as an execution method, but no state has attempted to use the untested method until now.
Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall said on Wednesday night that he believes the courts will allow the execution to proceed.
He said: â€œMy office stands ready to carry on the fight for Liz Sennett.
â€œTwo courts have now rejected Smithâ€™s claims. I remain confident that the Supreme Court will come down on the side of justice, and that Smithâ€™s execution will be carried out.â€
The victimâ€™s son, Charles Sennett Jr, said in an interview with WAAY-TV that Smith â€œhas to pay for what heâ€™s doneâ€.
â€œAnd some of these people out there say, â€˜Well, he doesnâ€™t need to suffer like that.â€™ Well, he didnâ€™t ask Mama how to suffer?â€ Mr Sennett Jr said. â€œThey just did it. They stabbed her â€” multiple times.â€
The state has predicted the nitrogen gas will cause unconsciousness within seconds and death within minutes.
A state attorney told the 11th Circuit that it will be â€œthe most painless and humane method of execution known to manâ€.
But some doctors and organisations have raised alarm about the stateâ€™s plan.
Robin M Maher, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Centre, said: â€œItâ€™s indefensible for Alabama officials to simply dismiss the very real risks this untested method presents and experiment on a man who has already survived one execution attempt.â€
Much of what is known about death by nitrogen gas comes from industrial accidents or suicide attempts.
Dr Philip Nitschke, a euthanasia expert who designed a suicide pod using nitrogen gas and appeared as an expert witness for Smith, said nitrogen can provide a peaceful, hypoxic death, but said he has concerns about Alabamaâ€™s proposal to use a mask.
Dr Nitschke told The Associated Press that Smithâ€™s facial hair, jaw movements and involuntary movements as he feels the effect of the nitrogen could impact the seal.
If there are leaks, Smith could continue to draw in enough oxygen, â€œto prolong into what could be a very rather macabre, slow process of slowly not getting enough oxygen,â€ Dr Nitschke said.
He said he could envision scenarios where the execution goes quickly or seriously awry.
Mr Marshallâ€™s office noted in court filings that Smith previously suggested nitrogen as an alternative method when fighting attempts to execute him by lethal injection.
Courts require inmates challenging execution methods to suggest another available alternative. Alabama at the time had not developed a nitrogen protocol.
Robert Grass, an attorney for Smith, told federal courts that they are challenging the specific way the state plans to administer the nitrogen. They argued the use of a gas mask puts Smith at risk of a prolonged and painful death or choking to death on his own vomit.
In 2020 euthanasia guidelines, the American Veterinary Medical Association wrote nitrogen hypoxia is not an acceptable euthanasia method for most mammals because the anoxic environment â€œis distressingâ€.
Experts appointed by the United Nations Human Rights Council cautioned they believe the execution method could violate the prohibition on torture.
Mrs Sennett, 45, was found dead on March 18 1988 in her home in Colbert County.
She had eight stab wounds in the chest and one on each side of her neck, according to the coroner.
Her husband, Charles Sennett Sr, killed himself when the investigation focused on him as a suspect, according to court documents.
John Forrest Parker, the other man convicted in the slaying, was executed in 2010.
In 1996, a jury recommended a life sentence by 11-1, but a judge overrode the recommendation and sentenced Smith to death.
Alabama no longer allows a judge to override a juryâ€™s death penalty decision.

Title: Serial criminal Lee Thomas jailed for flat burglary
Author: By Megi Rychlikova @CourtYorkPress Court Reporter
Content:
A burglar who left a man terrified to sleep in his own home has been jailed for three years and four months.
Police caught long-time criminal Lee Anthony Thomas red-handed with stolen items as he left the flat he had just raided, York Crown Court heard.
Benjamin Whittingham, prosecuting, said the victim was inside the flat asleep at the time and unaware he had been burgled until officers woke him up and handed him back his property.
Thomas has 264 previous convictions, more than half of them for theft and dishonesty and including convictions for house burglary and drug dealing. He was on two suspended prison sentences at the time of the flat burglary and has committed many offences in and around York.
In 2015, he carried out a raid in central York during which he confronted a woman as she dressed in her bedroom when he should have been attending court.
Thomas, formerly of York, and now of Victoria Road, Scarborough, denied burglary and tried to deceive a jury with what Judge Simon Hickey called a â€œludicrousâ€ account of what he was doing in the flatâ€™s back yard.
â€œYou are a big powerful man, if that man (the flatâ€™s occupant) had woken and confronted you, what wouldÂ have happened?â€ the judgeÂ toldÂ Thomas after the jury returned their guilty verdict in under an hour.
The judge quoted the victimâ€™s statement which said: â€œThe fact that someone has entered my flat whilst I was asleep makes me feel extremely scared, scared to be in my own home â€¦.. and left me worried to go to sleep.â€
Thomas had pleaded guilty to stealing a Â£1,200 bike chained to a post the day before the flat raid. Mr Whittingham said police caught him within hours.
He was jailed for three years and four months including three months previously suspended.
The jury wasÂ not told that police were in the Scarborough flatâ€™s area shortly before 8pm on September 28 because a woman had dialled 999 to report a man trying car doors.
They heard evidence an officer spotted Thomas behind the flat carrying the victimâ€™s TV remote and mobile phone and arrested him on suspicion of burglary.
The police officer and a colleague woke the victim, who had left his back door insecure so his cat could get in and out. They found one of Thomasâ€™ earphones on the floor near the back door. It had Thomasâ€™ DNA on it and he had the other matching earphone on him when arrested.
The victim told policeÂ the two stolen items had been in different rooms.
Thomas gave differing accounts to the police officer who arrested him, to the officer who interviewed him and in the witness box.
He denied going into the flat or stealing the items.Â He claimed he had gone to the back door to see if the flat occupant wanted toÂ sell a television which the burglar said he had found in the back yard.
Following the verdict, his barrister Rhianydd Clement said he had a doormanâ€™s licence and would get a job at the end of his sentence.
He had health problems including anxiety, depression, and paranoia, which would get worse in prison, and osteoporosis.

Title: Health warning to everyone who drinks energy drinks
Author: By Joshua Searle @josh_searle99 UK Today Editor
Content:
Young people who drink energy drinks regularly have been issued a health warning by experts.
Research suggests that just a few cans a week can result in insomnia and poor sleep in young people.
Experts found that young people aged 18 to 35 who consumed the drinks every day slept around half an hour less than those drinking them occasionally or not at all.
Among men, having two or three drinks a week meant they were 35% more likely to have a bedtime after midnight, 52% more likely to sleep less than six hours, and 60% more likely to wake in the night than those who did not or rarely drank them.
Research suggests that just a few cans of energy drink a week can result in insomnia and poor sleep in young people  (Image: Getty)
For women, they were 20% more likely to have a bedtime after midnight, 58% more likely to sleep less than six hours, and 24% more likely to wake in the night.
It comes after a study published last week said the sale of all energy drinks to young people and children in the UK should be banned because of links with anxiety, stress and suicidal thoughts.
Energy drinks often contain high levels of caffeine and sugar and are marketed as providing people with an energy boost.
The Government has consulted on a proposal to end the sale of energy drinks to children under 16 in England and has said it will set out a response in due course.
In the meantime, some larger retailers and supermarkets have voluntarily introduced a ban on the sale of energy drinks to children under 16.
Researchers have said, however, that the drinks can still be easily bought by children in places such as corner shops.
The latest study, published in BMJ Open and based on 53,266 Norwegian students, found the drinks are popular with young people.
Students in the study were asked how often they drank energy drinks, with responses including daily, weekly (including once a week, two to three times a week, and four to six times a week), monthly (one to three times), and seldom/never.
They were also asked detailed questions about their sleep patterns, such as when they went to bed and got up, how long it took them to fall asleep and if they woke in the night.
Insomnia was defined as problems falling and staying asleep and waking early on at least three nights a week, plus daytime sleepiness and tiredness for at least three days of the week, for at least three months.

Title: Turkeyâ€™s parliament approves Swedenâ€™s Nato membership
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
Turkish legislators have endorsed Swedenâ€™s Nato membership, paving the way for the previously nonaligned countryâ€™s entry into the military alliance.
The legislators ratified Swedenâ€™s accession protocol by 287 votes to 55, with four abstentions, on Tuesday.
It will come into effect after its publication in the Official Gazette, which is expected to be swift.
Hungary then becomes the only Nato ally not to have ratified Swedenâ€™s accession.
Nato-member Turkey had been delaying Swedenâ€™s membership for more than a year, accusing the country of being too lenient toward groups that Ankara regards as security threats.
It has been seeking concessions from Stockholm, including a tougher stance toward Kurdish militants militants and members of a network that Ankara blames for a failed coup in 2016.
Turkey had also been angered by a series of demonstrations by supporters of the outlawed Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party in Sweden as well as Koran-burning protests that roiled Muslim countries.
Last month, parliamentâ€™s foreign affairs committee gave its consent to Swedenâ€™s bid in the first stage of the legislative process, after Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sent its accession protocol to politicians for approval.
Arguing in favour of Swedenâ€™s membership last month, deputy foreign minister Burak Akcapar cited steps Sweden had taken to meet Turkish demands, including lifting restrictions on defence industry sales and amending anti-terrorism laws.
Sweden has pledged deeper co-operation with Turkey on counterterrorism and to support Turkeyâ€™s ambition to revive its European Union membership bid.
Turkeyâ€™s main opposition party also supported Swedenâ€™s membership in the alliance but a centre-right party and the countryâ€™s pro-Kurdish party declared they would oppose it.
â€œSwedenâ€™s steps concerning its extradition of wanted criminals or the fight against terrorism have remained limited and insufficient,â€ Musavat Dervisoglu, a politician from the Good Party told parliament.
Mr Erdogan has linked ratification of Swedenâ€™s Nato membership to the US Congressâ€™s approval of a Turkish request to purchase 40 new F-16 fighter jets and kits to modernise Turkeyâ€™s existing fleet.
He has also urged Canada and other Nato allies to lift arms embargoes on Turkey.
Koray Aydin, another Good Party politician, urged parliament to hold out on ratifying Swedenâ€™s accession until the F-16 sales and the modernisation kits are approved in Washington, saying Turkey would lose an important bargaining chip.
US President Joe Bidenâ€™s administration never formally tied the sale of the F-16s to Turkeyâ€™s ratification of Swedenâ€™s Nato membership.
However, numerous influential members of Congress had said they would not support the sale unless and until Turkey signs off on Swedenâ€™s accession to the alliance.
Administration officials say they expect relatively quick action on the F-16 sale after Turkeyâ€™s ratification of Swedenâ€™s Nato membership by Turkey
In Washington, National Security Council spokesman John Kirby said Sweden is â€œmore than ready to become a Nato allyâ€.
He said: â€œItâ€™s time for Sweden to become a Nato ally. They have a modern, advanced military â€“ one that weâ€™re very comfortable with. And theyâ€™ll add real significant military capabilities to the alliance.â€
Sweden and Finland abandoned their traditional positions of military nonalignment to seek protection under Natoâ€™s security umbrella following Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.
Finland joined the alliance in April, becoming Natoâ€™s 31st member, after Turkeyâ€™s parliament ratified the Nordic countryâ€™s bid.
Hungary has also stalled Swedenâ€™s bid, alleging that Swedish politicians have told â€œblatant liesâ€ about the condition of Hungaryâ€™s democracy.
Hungary has said it would not be the last to approve accession, although it was not clear when the Hungarian parliament intends to hold a vote.
Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor OrbÃ¡n announced on Tuesday that he sent a letter to his Swedish counterpart, Ulf Kristersson, inviting him to Budapest to discuss Swedenâ€™s entry into Nato.
Nato requires the unanimous approval of all existing members to expand, and Turkey and Hungary were the only countries that have been holding out, frustrating other Nato allies who had been pressing for Sweden and Finlandâ€™s swift accession.

Title: Post Officeâ€™s secret decision to sack forensic accountants branded â€˜disgustingâ€™
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
A campaigner fighting for justice in the Horizon scandal has branded the Post Officeâ€™s secret decision to sack independent forensic accountants who found bugs in their IT system as â€œdisgustingâ€.
Former subpostmistress Jo Hamilton said the move, uncovered in documents seen by the BBC, was like â€œtipping the board up when youâ€™re losingâ€ a game of Monopoly.
The decision was unearthed in minutes from a Post Office board sub-committee meeting in April 2014, named Project Sparrow, which the broadcaster said was with the full knowledge of Government.
Ms Hamilton, who was wrongfully convicted in 2008 of stealing thousands of pounds from a village shop in Hampshire, described it as a â€œmassive cover-upâ€, adding: â€œWe knew the Government were in it up to their necks.â€
The BBC said minutes from a meeting on April 9, 2014, showed the sub-committee asking for a paper to be prepared on the independent forensic accountants who were from a firm called Second Sight.
The sub-committee also asked for â€œoptions to support them or reduce their roleâ€.
Second Sight submitted a report in July 2013 which identified bugs that raised concerns over the reliability of Horizon data used to prosecute subpostmasters.
The Post Office was warned it was in breach of its legal duties as prosecuted subpostmasters should have been told about the bugs, but the board later expressed concern the review from the forensic accountants exposed them to wrongful conviction claims.
Three weeks after the first meeting, the sub-committee took the decision to bring the investigation of subpostmastersâ€™ cases â€œwithin the control of the Post Officeâ€ and removed Second Sight from its role of investigating the cases independently, the BBC said.
Ms Hamilton said â€œitâ€™s so wickedâ€ that the documents showed the Post Office planned to pay a total of only Â£1 million in â€œtoken paymentsâ€ to subpostmasters.
Heavily-redacted versions of the documents were made public in 2021 but the BBC has now seen the minutes of the meetings without redactions.
Reacting to the unearthed minutes from the 2014 meeting, Ms Hamilton told the PA news agency: â€œIt just confirms everything we know.
â€œWe knew the Government were in it up to their necks. We just knew, I knew Project Sparrow and we never had the names, but you can kind of guess whoâ€™s on it.
â€œYou can then say to all the business ministers â€˜who didnâ€™t know about this, honestly?â€™ because everyone has to have known â€“ right up to the top, I believe.
â€œIt just confirms what weâ€™ve kind of known â€“ you get a feeling that these kind of shenanigans were going on â€¦ and now weâ€™ve got it in black and white.
â€œYou can put it on the television and say â€˜go on, explain thatâ€™.â€
Speaking about the sacking of independent forensic accountants, Ms Hamilton said: â€œIt doesnâ€™t surprise meâ€¦ I mean, it is disgusting.
â€œThe Government are in this up to their necks and theyâ€™ve clearly thought â€˜oh my god, quickâ€™ â€“ itâ€™s like Monopoly, isnâ€™t it, tipping the board up when youâ€™re losing.
â€œThey know thereâ€™s nowhere else to go and theyâ€™ve got to do something crazy.
â€œIt was the true independence that meant they had to go, because they werenâ€™t going to toe the party line.
â€œItâ€™s a massive cover-up.â€
Addressing the Post Officeâ€™s attempt to pay subpostmasters â€œtoken paymentsâ€, Ms Hamilton told PA: â€œItâ€™s disgusting, isnâ€™t it?
â€œThey stole Â£60,000 of my money â€“ so how on earth they thought taking peopleâ€™s houses and everything else, they thought Â£1 million between us was going to actually cut it â€“ I mean, seriously, what were they thinking?
â€œPeople have gone to prison, weâ€™d all had criminal records and people had lost everything, and they thought that kind of money cuts it â€“ itâ€™s an absolute insult.
â€œPeople had that in bonuses â€¦ itâ€™s just disgusting, itâ€™s so wicked.â€
More than 700 branch managers were prosecuted by the Post Office after Fujitsuâ€™s faulty accounting softwareÂ Horizon made it look as though money was missing from their shops.
The saga prompted an outcry across the country after it was dramatised in the ITV series Mr Bates vs The Post Office earlier this month.
Hundreds of subpostmasters are awaiting compensation despite the Government announcing that those who have had convictions quashed are eligible for Â£600,000 payouts.
A Post Office spokesman said: â€œIt is not appropriate for the Post Office to comment on allegations being made outside of the inquiry, whose role it is to consider all of the evidence on the issues it is examining and independently reach conclusions.
â€œWe fully share the public inquiryâ€™s aims to get to the truth of what happened in the past and accountability.â€
A spokeswoman for the Prime Minister said Number 10 was taking the â€œthose reports extremely seriouslyâ€.
She added: â€œIt is right that we have an inquiry to look into this.
â€œAnd for that reason, with that ongoing, I wonâ€™t comment on matters of potential interest to the inquiry, particularly also given it relates to a previous administration.â€
The PMâ€™s spokeswoman said Number 10 are waiting for the Post Office Horizon IT inquiry to conclude and will â€œact accordinglyâ€ after being asked whether further compensation could be offered if it is found the Government was aware of attempts to cover-up issues relating to Horizon.
The Department for Business and Trade declined to comment.

Title: UK rail tickets prices slashed in Great British Rail Sale
Author: By Rebecca Carey becca_carey_ Deputy Head of Editorial SEO

Popular journeysÂ passengers could claim savings on tickets for include:

Title: York and North Yorkshire combined authority to have 54 staff
Author: By Thomas Barrett
Content:
THE new York and North Yorkshire Combined Authority will employ 54 staff at a cost of Â£4.5 million a year, it has been revealed.
The authority will be led by the regionâ€™s first-ever mayor with voters going to the polls on May 2.
Later today, councillors at North Yorkshire Council and City of York Council will discuss a report that details the new mayorâ€™s budget in their first year.
The Local Democracy Reporting Service asked the office that is overseeing the creation of the combined authority for clarity on how many staff it will hire and what roles they will be doing.
James Farrar, interim director of transition, said the 54 officers will help to deliver Â£56 million of â€œtransformational programmesâ€ related to housing, education, business and net zero.
They will also work to win additional investment and support businesses in the region.
Staff currently working in the office of Zoe Metcalfe, Police, Fire and Crime Commissioner, will transfer into the combined authority.
Regarding what the new mayor will be paid, an independent panel will make a recommendation after the election.
According to the website citymayors.com, West Yorkshire mayor Tracey Brabin is paid an annual allowance of Â£106,837, South Yorkshire mayor Dan Jarvis receives Â£79,000 and Tees Valley mayor Ben Houchen is paid Â£65,000.
Mr Farrar added: â€œThe launch of the combined authority marks a historic moment for York and North Yorkshire as powers and funds previously held by Westminster have been devolved to local decision makers. That means more local controls and investment into local priorities.â€
Powers used by mayors elsewhere in the country have included taking buses back into public ownership, like Labourâ€™s Andy Burnham has done in Greater Manchester.
Conservative Tees Valley mayor Ben Houchen brought Teeside International Airport into public ownership in 2018 but heâ€™s faced criticism over use of public money in the Redcar Steelworks project.Â Mr Houchen has strongly denied any wrongdoing.
Cllr Andy Brown (Green Party, Aire Valley) said he would have preferred to see one mayor for the whole of Yorkshire which he believes could assert more influence in Westminster.
But he said he hopes the role will lead to more investment in the region.
Cllr Brown said: â€œLots of little mayors with different powers risks becoming a mess where people in London offer local leaders funding to do what they are told.
Joanna Marchong, investigations campaign manager of campaign group the Taxpayersâ€™ Alliance said residents â€œwill be sceptical of a huge pay billâ€ amidst talk of savings.
She added:Â â€œCombined authorities often deliver cheaper, more efficient services and York and North Yorkshire combined authority should be no exception. Officials must iron out the details and ensure residents are getting value for money.â€

Title: Glaisdale residents propose better road signage following River deaths
Author: By Anttoni James Numminen
Content:
Glaisdale residents have expressed concerns about local road signage following a recent tragic incident.
Following the incident at Rake Lane ford in Glaisdale last December, which left three people dead, members of the local parish council have expressed their condolences and called for improved signage.
At a meeting of Glaisdale Parish Council on Thursday, January 18, residents raised concerns over the number of 4Ã—4 drivers â€œwho disregard the existing signage even when conditions are adverseâ€.
READ MORE:Â North Yorkshire Police name Esk River drowning victims
According to draft minutes, residents said that â€œmany drivers who attempt the crossing are not local and are unaware of the river conditions on either side of the ford.â€
At the meeting, North Yorkshire Policeâ€™s PCSO Pete Lewis outlined the incident as well as potential solutions that have been put forward.
Proposed options included permanently closing the road to vehicles or installing lockable gates at both ends of the road.
Other suggestions proposed installing a metal barrier downstream of the ford or installing automatic barriers at each side of the approaches to the ford â€œwhich operate when flood level sensors are activated and temporarily closing the roadâ€.
Whilst many of the proposals were described as â€œextremely unlikelyâ€ and expensive, it was agreed that no actions would be proposed or agreed until the coronerâ€™s verdict on the deaths has been pronounced.
The incident on December 28 led to the deaths of Scott Thomas Daddy, Leslie Forbes, and Kenneth Patrick Hibbins when a 4Ã—4 vehicle was â€œswept awayâ€ as it tried to cross a river.
The draft minutes state that the â€œmost positive outcome from the discussion has been the almost universal acknowledgement that much better signage is necessary at this locationâ€.
It was also suggested at the parish council meeting that information should be given on the signs â€œas to how dangerous this ford is during flooding and that several lives have been lost when attempts are made to cross in flood conditionsâ€.
North Yorkshire Councilâ€™s highways representative, Richard Marr, agreed about that â€œnecessityâ€, according to the minutes.
The parish council concluded that any action â€œmust wait until all investigations are complete and the coroner has issued a verdict on the deathsâ€.
The chairman expressed condolences to the â€œfamily and friends of the deceased and thanked the emergency services and local residents for their efforts during the incidentâ€.

Title: Samuel Cousins racially insulted doorman at Tank & Paddle
Author: By Megi Rychlikova @CourtYorkPress Court Reporter
Content:
A DRINKERÂ who racially insulted a doorman at a city centre pub has been handed a community order.
Samuel Cousins, 24, must also pay the victim compensation.
His solicitor Craig Robertson, quoting the doormanâ€™s witness statement, said the victim had made comments about the clothes worn by Cousinâ€™s female companion and her â€œposteriorâ€.
Cousins, of Alder Way, New Earswick, pleaded guilty to two racially aggravated public order offences.
â€œThe doorman was only doing his job,â€ district judge Orla Austin told Cousins at York Magistrates' Court.
â€œHe was completely innocent. He doesnâ€™t go to work to be abused, particularly not at a racial level.â€
She ordered Cousins to do a 12-month community order with 20 daysâ€™ rehabilitative activities and 100 hoursâ€™ unpaid work. He must also pay a total of Â£299, consisting of Â£100 compensation to the doorman, a Â£114 statutory surcharge and Â£85 prosecution costs.
The court heard that Cousins was at the Tank & Paddle in Bridge Street next to Ouse Bridge on May 18.
He was racially insulting to the doorman, referring to his appearance and swearing asÂ  he made remarks about what the doormanÂ should do.
He was still being racially abusive when police arrested him outside Jalou nearby at the bottom of Micklegate.
Mr Robertson said although Cousins had previous convictions, his last had been in 2019.
Cousins had been drinking and accepted he had responded inappropriately and wrongly to the doormanâ€™s comments.
He had recently got a job, court heard.

Title: Three arrested after police drugs raid in Acomb, York
Author: By Harry Booth Reporter
Content:
THREE people have been arrested following a police drugs raid in Acomb, York.
Officers from North Yorkshire Police arrested two men in their 50s and a woman in her 40s during the operation this morning (January 26).
A police spokesman said they entered a flat in Acomb and found bags of what is believed to be heroin during a search, which have since been sent for forensic analysis.
The operation was led by York outer neighbourhood policing team, supported by specialist search teams, and carried out during neighbourhood policing week, which isÂ a nationwide event to highlight the role of local policing in communities.
TheyÂ said: "If you have information about drug dealing in your community, tell us by visiting the North Yorkshire Police website, then clicking 'report' and reporting a crime."
You can also contact Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

Title: Threats against Donaldson over powersharing talks condemned in Parliament
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
Threats made against DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson for engaging with the UK Government as part of efforts to restore powersharing have sparked condemnation.
The MP for Lagan Valley revealed he had been targeted as he urged others in the wider unionist movement against opposing a deal that had yet to be agreed.
His remarks came after Conservative former Northern Ireland secretary Julian Smith suggested the DUP had negotiated a â€œvery good dealâ€ on issues around post-Brexit trade arrangements.
The party has maintained an almost two-year boycott of the Stormont institutions in protest at internal economic barriers between Great Britain and Northern Ireland, following the UKâ€™s departure from the EU.
Amid speculation an agreement is near to being reached, the UK Government tabled new legislation aimed at providing a window for this to be achieved.
Under the law governing the formation of a devolved administration in Belfast, the Government assumes a legal duty to call a snap assembly election once a deadline for forming a ministerial executive is passed.
The Northern Ireland (Executive Formation) Bill, which sets a new cut-off of February 8, cleared both the Commons and Lords on Wednesday.
Speaking in the Commons, Sir Jeffrey said: â€œAs a result of the actions my party has taken, the EU were brought back to the table, there were negotiations, changes have occurred, and further change will come as a result of our actions.â€
In advance of any agreement he called on the Secretary of State release funding for public sector pay rises, which had been the subject of strike action.
Sir Jeffrey said threats would not stop him from engaging with the Government.
He said: â€œIâ€™m proud of the service that I have given, unlike some others, to my country when I put on the uniform of the Ulster Defence Regiment to protect everyone in the community from terrorism and violence.
â€œAnd yet today, because of the stirring up that is going on, I was threatened, threatened by those who never put on a uniform, by those who havenâ€™t served our country.â€
He added: â€œThey are threatening people like me, whoâ€™s working day and night to try and find solutions and to move Northern Ireland forward on a basis that the vast majority of people can support.
â€œWell I would just say this to those who stir up, and those who threaten: the provisional IRA attacked me in the past and it didnâ€™t deflect me from the task that I have, and my colleagues have, to do our job and to get the best that we can for Northern Ireland.â€
In a message to fellow unionists in Northern Ireland, Sir Jeffrey said earlier: â€œWait until an agreement is reached before you make your final verdict, assess the progress that has been made before you reach your conclusion.â€
He said â€œthere are someâ€, a â€œtiny minorityâ€, who â€œdonâ€™t want Stormont backâ€, but said his party is â€œcommitted to getting a solution, to moving things forward, to making progress, to resolving the issues that have harmed Northern Irelandâ€.
Northern Ireland Secretary Chris Heaton-Harris described those who had sought to threaten Sir Jeffrey as â€œcowards and idiotsâ€.
Speaking in Parliament, former Ulster Unionist leader Lord Empey condemned those behind the attempts at intimidation.
The peer said: â€œThe question is what did they ever achieve? What did they ever get us? More misery, more deaths and destruction, no progress. So if anything has come out of all of this, it is that is not the way to go forward.â€
Expressing her shock, former first minister and DUP leader Baroness Foster of Aghadrumsee, said: â€œIt appears that there is nothing new under the sun.
â€œThese people who hide in the shadows and use the internet, in the way that we have talked about on so many occasions, seek to do damage and to push things in a particular way.
â€œI send my solidarity to Sir Jeffrey and I am sure the whole House will want to echo that in respect of the threats that he has received.â€
Northern Ireland Office minister Lord Caine said: â€œI know I speak for all members of this House when we pass on our support for him (Sir Jeffrey) and wish him well.â€
On the prospect of an agreement, he added: â€œOf course we all want to see progress within the next fortnight. At the moment there is no deal. We very much hope there will be one in the space of time this legislation provides.â€
Senior Tory MP Mr Smith said: â€œ(Sir Jeffrey Donaldson) and his team, I understand, seem to have negotiated also a very good deal with the Government on issues around the Windsor Framework and I hope in the coming days and weeks we will be able to see the results of that work.â€

Title: Knife crime â€˜will not be fixed overnightâ€™ by crackdown on zombie-style blades
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
Knife crime will not be tackled â€œovernightâ€ by the Governmentâ€™s latest ban on zombie-style blades and a fourth crackdown could be announced in future, the policing minister has said.
Chris Philp did not rule out further action being taken on certain types of swords if necessary amid calls to widen the scope of the prohibition.
Fresh legislation will be laid in Parliament on Thursday in order to close what ministers have described as a loophole within an existing ban on zombie-style weapons.
Previous attempts to ban the knives have defined them as having threatening images or words on them. But the new law will mean that blades without any logos will also be recognised if they have other key features, such as a cutting or serrated edge, the Home Office says.
This is the Governmentâ€™s third attempt at banning the blades since 2016, and campaigners including actor Idris Elba have expressed concern thatÂ other weapons such as swords are still not included in the legislation.
Speaking to broadcasters on Thursdayâ€™s morning media round, the policing minister said he had spoken with Elba in the Home Office on Wednesday about the issue and suggested the ban could be expanded again.
He told BBC Radio 4â€™s Today programme: â€œThe ban weâ€™re introducing in Parliament today specifies the design of the bladed articleâ€¦ someÂ swordsÂ could fall into that definition.
â€œA regularÂ sword, like the sort a historic soldier might carry, would probably not qualify. It would depend on the design, but they may not qualify. Thatâ€™s because there are a number of issues likeâ€¦ some religions have thoseÂ swords.â€
He added: â€œBut the commitment that the Government will make, and Iâ€™ll make now, is that if we find in the future (that) there are other things that need to be brought into the scope, then we can do another statutory instrument like the one weâ€™re doing today to ban those, because itâ€™s much faster than using primary legislation.â€
The new ban is an â€œimportant partâ€ of the Governmentâ€™s overall approach to tackling knife crime but the problem will not immediately disappear, the minister said.
Asked whether the legislation laid on ThursdayÂ will combat the issue comprehensively, he told LBC: â€œItâ€™s a step forward, but Iâ€™m not going to claim itâ€™s going to overnight fix all the issues with knife crime, but itâ€™s anÂ importantÂ partÂ of it.â€
Figures published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) on Thursday show knife crime offences recorded by police forces in England and Wales rose year-on-year but have not yet returned to levels seen before the Covid-19 pandemic.
In the year to September 2023, there were 240 killings involving knives and other sharp instruments, which was broadly unchanged on the 241 recorded in the previous year and also lower than pre-pandemic figures.
Offences involving knives or sharp instruments increased by 5% (48,716 offences) compared with the year ending Sept 2022 (46,367 offences), but remain 5% lower compared with the year ending March 2020 (51,228 offences).
Excludes Devon and Cornwall and Greater Manchester Police. pic.twitter.com/5Zw3rEahzM
â€” Office for National Statistics (ONS) (@ONS) January 25, 2024
More than 19,000 cautions and convictions were handed out for possession of a knife or offensive weapon in the year ending March 2023, according to sentencing statistics from the Ministry of Justice.
Elba welcomed the new ban as a â€œstep in the right directionâ€ but expressed reservations about whether it will work as gaps remain in the legislation.
â€œUnfortunately it doesnâ€™t ban all knives, including swords. However, the significant step towards zombie knives and machetes is something that I think is really important,â€ he said.
â€œWeâ€™ve seen in the past that it hasnâ€™t achievedâ€¦ in fact you see knife crime rise in certain instances. But I do think there is a slightly more joined-up approach.â€
We need to protect young people from the rising epidemic of knife crime.
Thatâ€™s exactly what Labourâ€™s plan will do ğŸ‘‡
â€” The Labour Party (@UKLabour) January 25, 2024
Shadow home secretary Yvette Cooper said the Government has announced its proposals â€œabout 16 times beforeâ€ and a â€œmuch broader banâ€ is needed.
â€œItâ€™s got to include things like the ninja swords and other dangerous weapons as well, and thereâ€™s got to be stronger penalties for the online marketplaces who are still profiting from the sale of illegal knives,â€ she told Sky News.
Meanwhile, Labour is focusing on a youth programme to tackle knife crime, pledging Â£100 million for a nationwide initiative to support young people at risk of being drawn into violence.
Alongside the programme, it is also promising â€œreal consequencesâ€ for those who offend, with an end to â€œempty warnings and apology lettersâ€ for those guilty of possession.
The Conservatives said the announcement is â€œjust another reheated pledge from the Labour Party using money they have already spent seven timesâ€.

Title: â€˜No obvious alternativeâ€™ to Sunak as Tory leader among 2019 party backers â€“ poll
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
There are â€œno obvious alternativesâ€ to Rishi Sunak as Conservative leader for winning back those who voted for the party in 2019, a new poll has suggested.
Mr Sunakâ€™s continued leadership of his party came under renewed speculation this week after Sir Simon Clarke, a senior ally of former prime minister Liz Truss, said the Tories would suffer a â€œmassacreâ€ at the next election if they did not ditch Mr Sunak.
But a poll by Ipsos UK suggests there may be few alternatives to Mr Sunak in the eyes of 2019 Conservative voters, with the Prime Minister enjoying a higher favourability rating than the rest of his front bench.
Some 42% of 2019 Tory voters said they had a favourable view of Mr Sunak, with Chancellor Jeremy Hunt trailing on 38% and Home Secretary James Cleverly on 28%.
The Prime Ministerâ€™s net favourability rating of +13 was also much higher than those of his Chancellor and Home Secretary, on +7 and +2 respectively.
There was also little difference between Mr Sunak and possible candidates from outside the parliamentary Conservative party.
Former prime minister Boris Johnson had a favourability rating among 2019 Tory voters of 43%, but at 34% his unfavourability rating was higher than that of Mr Sunak.
Reform UK founder and honorary president Nigel Farage, suggested by some as a possible future Conservative leader, was also virtually neck-and-neck with Mr Sunak in terms of popularity.
The former MEP was viewed favourably by 43% of 2019 Conservatives, only one point more than Mr Sunak, and was viewed unfavourably by 29%, tied with the Prime Minister.
Keiran Pedley, director of politics at Ipsos, said: â€œWith a majority of Britons unfavourable towards Rishi Sunak, six in 10 saying things are heading in the wrong direction and Labour maintaining a large poll lead over the Conservatives in voter preferences, leadership speculation is to be expected.
â€œHowever, it is unclear who would do a better job. No obvious alternative stands out amongst 2019 Conservative voters so far.
â€œPlus, given at least half of Britons have held unfavourable opinions towards the Conservative Party since early 2022, itâ€™s not a given that a new leader will improve the party brand any time soon.â€
The poll, which surveyed 1,087 British adults between January 12 and 14, also found that around a fifth of 2019 Conservative voters now said they were likely to consider voting for Labour, while 28% said they would consider voting for Reform.

Title: Monk convicted of abusing children describes victims as â€˜unhingedâ€™ at inquiry
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
A 90-year-old man who physically and sexually abused boys in his care at a residential school in the 1960s has branded his victims â€œunhingedâ€ and said they should be investigated by police for â€œtelling liesâ€.
Michael Murphy appeared by video link at the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry on Wednesday from HMP Edinburgh, where he is serving a sentence for physically and sexually abusing children while he was a social worker with the De La Salle Brothers in Gartmore, Stirlingshire, and St Josephâ€™s in Tranent, East Lothian, between 1961 and 1991.
Murphy continued to deny he was responsible for abusing boys in his care while he was working at the establishment, and described those who had brought allegations, resulting in convictions in 2003, 2016 and 2021, as â€œcharactersâ€ who were motivated to complain for â€œfinancial gainâ€.
The former monk became a member of the De La Salle brothers in 1956 and was posted to St Ninianâ€™s School in Gartmore in 1961.
Murphy was asked by lead counsel to the inquiry, Colin MacAulay KC, how he felt about the allegations.
Murphy said: â€œAll of these characters and complainers, they are unhinged â€¦ and I think they need to be checked out by the police and need to be investigated about all of these lies they have told.â€
During Wednesdayâ€™s evidence, the inquiry heard Murphy had been convicted of 54 charges of physical and sexual abuse, including incidents where he would hit boys on the bottom with an implement made of three 16in shoe laces if they were misbehaving, and that he administered electric shocks to boys using a small generator he called â€œthe ticklerâ€.
The inquiry also heard about an incident where Murphy assaulted a boy so badly, he broke his arm and had to be taken to hospital.
Murphy downplayed the incident and attempted to place blame on the child, saying the youngster had â€œabusedâ€ him because of his â€œfootwearâ€ and described it as a â€œmisunderstandingâ€.
He said: â€œI had a misunderstanding with a boy about my footwear and my bad foot.
â€œI gave him an arm twist. I twisted his arm.
â€œThatâ€™s all.â€
Lead counsel to the inquiry Colin MacAulay KC put it to Murphy that the child sustained a broken arm as a consequence.
Murphy said: â€œHe fractured a wee bone on his arm.â€
He was later asked about administering electric shocks to children, with one incident causing burns to a boyâ€™s hand.
Murphy continued to insist he was not administering shocks and said the sensation went along the muscle of the hands and that the complainer was â€œtelling liesâ€.
Mr MacAulay asked Murphy if he had ever administered a shock through the testicles.
Murphy denied he had and said his convictions were â€œfalseâ€.
He said he had been entrusted with the care of around 90 children on his own, with very little training in how to look after them.
When asked to explain why so many people came forward regarding Murphyâ€™s treatment of the children, he said there had been â€œcollusionâ€.
Mr MacAulay asked Murphy: â€œWhy are they picking on you?â€
Murphy responded: â€œI have already said it is because I am the only one alive today.
â€œIt is all about compensation.â€
Meanwhile, the inquiry also heard from a teacher at St Josephâ€™s between 1978 and 1994, known simply as William, who was accused of hitting boys with blackboard dusters and making them sniff ammonia as forms of discipline.
William told the inquiry he used blackboard dusters to tackle â€œclassroom nonsenseâ€ and said the boys would often throw the dusters back at him.
He insisted he did not use physical punishment and witnessed it at the school only once when a boy had taken off the handbrake on a minibus.
When asked about boys being made to smell ammonia, he said he had been talking about â€œsmelling saltsâ€ and told the boys he could let them smell ammonia.
He said the accusations of abuse towards the boys were â€œupsettingâ€ because he believed he had â€œalways got on wellâ€ with them and had spent much of his career working with children who had social, behavioural and emotional difficulties.
William has not been convicted of any offences related to the allegations.
Later on Wednesday, a social worker denied accusations of abuse against him when he worked in residential care and said no behaviour he would categorise as abuse took place.
No criminal complaints have been made against the man, who gave evidence to the inquiry under the pseudonym Dominic.
He worked at institutions run by the De La Salle brothers during the 1980s.
Dominic had been accused of hitting boys and looking at them inappropriately while they were changing.
He strenuously denied the accusations put to him at the inquiry.
He said he had never witnessed any physical punishment towards the children in his care, and he described St Josephâ€™s as a â€œremarkableâ€ place that was â€œquite progressiveâ€ with an approach that would be described as â€œrestorativeâ€ nowadays.
Dominic also discussed Murphyâ€™s electric generator and the sensation it gave as â€œunderwhelmingâ€.
He was asked by Mr MacAulay if he had ever seen any abuse at St Josephâ€™s during his time there.
He said: â€œI honestly did not think I saw behaviour with any kid that I would consider to be abusive.â€
In 2017, the De La Salle Brothers used the Scottish Child Abuse Inquiry to apologise to victims who had suffered abuse within their care.
The spokesman for the De La Salle Brothers, David Anderson, said nothing could be said to defend the mistreatment of children.
â€œWhere a brother at any of these schools was responsible for the mistreatment of a child or young adult entrusted to the congregationâ€™s care, the congregation offers an unreserved apology,â€ he said at the time.
The inquiry, before Lady Smith, continues.

Title: Death toll rises to 12 with dozens injured in a strike on a crowded Gaza shelter
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
A United Nations official says the death toll from a strike on a crowded shelter in Gaza has risen to 12, with more than 75 wounded.
Thomas White, a senior official with the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA, said on Thursday that 15 of those wounded were in critical condition.
UNRWA says two tank shells hit a building in a shelter housing thousands of displaced Palestinians on Wednesday in the southern city of Khan Younis, which has seen heavy fighting in recent days.
The building caught fire, it said.
It did not directly blame Israel, which is the only party to the conflict that has tanks.
The Israeli military said it has â€œcurrently ruled outâ€ that the strike was carried out by its aircraft or artillery but was still investigating. It says the building might have been hit by a Hamas rocket.
The fighting in Khan Younis has isolated its two main hospitals, Nasser and Al-Amal, stranding hundreds of patients and thousands of displaced people inside.
Mr White says a third hospital was evacuated overnight, and that among the patients who departed were women who had just undergone caesarean sections.
Thousands of people rushed to escape farther south in recent days, crowding into shelters and tent camps near the border with Egypt.
The Health Ministry in Gaza says more than 25,700 people have been killed and another 63,000 wounded in the enclave since the October 7 attack in southern Israel, when militants from Gaza killed around 1,200 people and took about 250 hostages.

Title: Ex-investigator forced to give evidence at Horizon inquiry as â€˜time was limitedâ€™
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
A Post Office investigator involved in the probe of a subpostmaster who died before his wrongful conviction was overturned has had to be forced to give evidence at the Horizon IT inquiry as his â€œtime was limitedâ€.
Raymond Grant submitted a â€œminimumâ€ witness statement that was only a little over two pages long â€“ blaming his â€œ10 to 11-hourâ€ working days and moving house.
Mr Grant said he was looking after homeless residents in a Christian shelter during December where â€œthere are a lot of activities going onâ€.
Counsel to the inquiry Jason Beer KC said he would see if the witness could improve on his statement, before adding: â€œNow that carol services and dog walking are out of the wayâ€.
Mr Grant investigated William Quarm, who was convicted in 2010 of stealing from his Post Office branch in North Uist, Scotland and ordered to carry out 150 hours of unpaid work.
He died two years later at the age of 69 and his conviction was successfully quashed in the Court of Criminal Appeal in Edinburgh last year.
Asked by counsel to the inquiry Jason Beer KC why his witness statement was so short on Wednesday, Mr Grant said: â€œMy current role is I work in a homeless centre for a Christian organisation â€“ it has 30 residents in it.
â€œI am the programme manager in that unit and my job is to ensure that these residents get the level of respect and dignity that they deserve.
â€œPart of the role is to ensure that at that time of the year, December in a Christian calendar, there are a lot of activities going on.
â€œWe were, at that point, five members of staff short.
â€œI was working somewhere in the region of 10 to 11-hour days â€“ I was going home, walking my dog and at the same time, the home where I was living, I was asked to vacate it by December 31.â€
He continued: â€œSo I was in the process of trying to purchase a property, view a property, deal with conveyancing issues, dealing with mortgage arrangements â€“ so there was a clear clash of priorities as far as I was concerned.
â€œI chose my current job as being the most important as it directly affected 20 members of staff and 29 homeless residents.
â€œI fully understand my obligations to this important Post Office Horizon IT inquiry â€“ however, my time was limited, for all the things that Iâ€™ve said previously.
â€œI managed to negotiate an extra month on my rented property, and I have to be out of that by the 31st (of January).â€
Mr Grant said he spoke with one of the senior lawyers from the inquiry who made it clear their priorities were â€œdifferentâ€ from his own.
He continued: â€œReading, digesting, understanding an inordinate amount of documents â€“ 450, at that time, subsequently another 350 on top of that.â€
Mr Beer interjected: â€œWhen you say documents, you mean pages?â€
Mr Grant responded: â€œYes sorry, I beg your pardon.
â€œAnd then having to prepare a detailed statement of my memory from the time of employment, which was 16 years ago, to any involvement in any Post Office investigation.â€
Mr Grant said he was set a deadline of January 2 to provide answers to questions posed by the inquiryâ€™s legal team and after saying it was â€œnot physically possibleâ€, he was told he would â€œpotentially be breaking the lawâ€.
â€œMy pleadings were going on deaf ears,â€ he said.
â€œI explained about me moving home, and the caller (said) I should provide details of my conveyancing lawyers so that I could be checked up on.â€
Mr Beer then said: â€œSo, in short, itâ€™s a clash of priorities.â€
Mr Grant continued: â€œThe next level of communication I had was that Sheriff officers appeared at my door and issued me with a section 21 notice, to say that I had to comply and be here today.â€
Mr Beer responded: â€œThatâ€™s right, youâ€™re here under the threat of the exercise of compulsory powers â€“ we had to serve a section 21 notice.â€
The former Post Office investigator said: â€œYes, I agree with that.
â€œThat kind of focussed me and in my time I was then able to â€“ my first day off during that was January 1 following a 10-hour night shift during New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Yearâ€™s morning.
â€œThat was when I drafted this minimum statement to comply with the section 21 order.
â€œI apologise to the court, but for all the reasons Iâ€™ve said, thatâ€™s the reason why itâ€™s such a short statement.â€
Mr Beer said: â€œWell letâ€™s see if we can improve on that today, now that carol services and dog walking are out of the way.â€

Title: Two million to be cut off from gas and electricity this winter â€“ Citizens Advice
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
More than two million people will have their gas and electricity cut off this winter because they cannot afford to top up their prepayment meter, Citizens Advice has said.
The charity said it was concerned that having no gas and electricity would not be a â€œone-offâ€ experience for many, after finding that 1.7 million people disconnected at least once a month last year.
Some 800,000 people went for more than 24 hours without gas and electricity last year because they could not afford to top up, leaving them unable to make a hot meal or take a warm shower.
The charity raised its concerns after Ofgem announced that it had permitted EDF, Octopus and Scottish Power to return to forcibly fitting prepayment meters (PPMs) after they were temporarily banned after a scandal around the practice.
Citizens Advice said it expected this to be its busiest winter for helping people who cannot afford to top up, with its latest research suggesting that more than five million people live in households that are in debt to their energy supplier, putting them at risk of debt collection and being forced on to a prepayment meter.
Its survey found that one in four people cannot afford their essential bills and one in 10 households have had to borrow money in the past six months to cover their energy bills.
Half of those in debt to their energy supplier (49%) have turned off the heating in their homes, while almost three million people live in households where they have skipped meals, cut back on food spending or sold or pawned possessions in the last year to save money to keep their meter topped up, the survey found.
Citizens Advice said it wanted to see urgent reform of the warm home discount, which had failed to keep pace with rising prices and should be increased and made available to a wider range of households.
The charity also wants the Government to work with Ofgem to develop a joint action plan to deal with energy debt, including increased funding for support to help meet spiralling demand.
Citizens Advice said it was particularly worried about households with children under four, who were twice as likely to be in debt and to be forced to disconnect from their gas and electricity than those without children.
Half of prepayment meter users with children under four had disconnected in the past year because they could not afford to top up, compared with a quarter (23%) of people with no children, the charity found.
Citizens Advice chief executive Dame Clare Moriarty said: â€œOur frontline advisers are helping more people than ever who canâ€™t pay their energy bill.
â€œRecord numbers are in debt to their supplier and millions with a prepayment meter are too often going without heating and hot meals because they canâ€™t afford to top up.
â€œThe Government has not provided new energy bill support for those in need and has run out of time to develop the long-term approach it promised by April 2024.
â€œWithout immediate action, we risk re-running this same crisis every winter.â€
An Ofgem spokesman said: â€œOfgem shares the concerns of Citizens Advice about the issue of rising debt and customers self-disconnecting from their energy supply amid the wider cost of living pressures.
â€œWe already have introduced tougher rules to make sure that energy companies do more to spot the signs when a customer may be struggling and step in to offer support, including working out affordable payment plans and providing emergency credit to reduce the risk of self-disconnection.
â€œWe work closely with Citizens Advice and other consumer groups and charities to address the issues people are facing and we will continue to explore more options to help struggling and vulnerable customers.â€
A Department for Energy Security and Net Zero spokesman said: â€œWe recognise the cost-of-living challenges families are facing, which is why we are spending Â£104 billion supporting households with their bills.
â€œWhile energy prices are lower than last winter, our Energy Price Guarantee remains in place to protect people until April, and we encourage anyone experiencing difficulties with their energy bills to speak with their supplier.
â€œWeâ€™re also continuing to support the most vulnerable, with three million households expected to benefit from the Â£150 Warm Home Discount, Â£900 for those on means-tested benefits, and an extra Â£150 for disabled people.â€
Vulnerable customers can sign up for assistance via the free priority services register via the Ofgem website, http://www.ofgem.gov.uk/get-help-your-supplier-priority-services-register.
Yonder surveyed 4,338 adults in Great Britain between December 6-18.

Title: Councils claim funding settlement benefits wealthier areas
Author: By PA News Agency
Content:
Important elements of the funding settlement for councils this year disproportionately benefit richer areas and fail to take into account a range of growing demand pressures, according to local authorities serving some of the poorest communities.
In its response to the Governmentâ€™s consultation on the settlement for 2024/25 published last month, the Special Interest Group of Municipal Authorities (Sigoma) said the Governmentâ€™s approach shows funding decisions are increasingly less focused on local needs, raising the risk that more councils will declare effective bankruptcy.
Sigoma, which represents 47 urban councils in some of the most deprived areas in England, said the proposals are in line with a policy statement issued in 2022, before the full emergence of severe problems such asÂ  workforce pressures and spiralling costs in a â€œbrokenâ€ childrenâ€™s social care market.
The consultation response, shared exclusively with the PA news agency, raises concerns that wealthier areas are being prioritised because of the way funding is allocated.
Sigoma said an increasing reliance on council tax to boost councilsâ€™ core spending power means people are forced to pay for essential services that should be funded by the Government.
This approach does not take into account variations in the level of council tax that can be generated in different areas, leaving poorer areas disadvantaged by having a higher proportion of properties in lower, cheaper bands.
This means either average council tax charges must be much higher in areas where many households can least afford them, to cover the shortfall, or there is significantly less to spend despite higher demand for services.
Sigoma also questioned the fairness of an effort to eliminate what is known as â€œnegative revenue support grantâ€, whereby councils that receive more revenue than they need from local charges pay back funding to central Government.
The move to compensate affected councils, which mostly benefits district councils in shire areas, involves hundreds of million of pounds being redirected â€œto the detriment of poorer areasâ€, Sigoma said.
â€œThis is further evidence of the need for a full fair funding review of the local government finance system,â€ it added.
Concerns were also raised about the Governmentâ€™s â€œfunding guaranteeâ€, which aims to ensure councils get a 3% annual increase in their core spending power before decisions have been taken on efficiencies, use of financial reserves and council tax levels.
However, analysis by Sigoma shows that the 30% most deprived authorities got nothing from the funding guarantee, while the 10% least deprived areas received the most per household.
Sigoma argue that the guarantee is flawed because it is calculated without recognising the level of revenue available to councils.
This imbalance is illustrated by a largely flat increase in councilsâ€™ core spending power across all levels of deprivation in 2024/25, when in the past less wealthy areas received higher increases to cover demand on services.
Sigomaâ€™s intervention comes as 44 Conservative MPs have written to the Prime Minister to urge him to rethink funding plans for councils.
They said they are â€œexceptionally concernedâ€ that their local councils are on the verge of financial crisis and will be forced to hike council tax and cut services in an election year.
Sir Stephen Houghton, Sigoma chairman and Labour leader of Barnsley Council, said the finance settlement fails to cover increasing costs and account for rising demand.
He said: â€œThese pressures, following a decade of cuts, have pushed many councils to the brink.
â€œThe settlement also failed to distribute funding fairly. Over the last 14 years, the method of allocating funding has been moving further and further from a needs basis, resulting in an ever-growing gap between councils in the richest and poorest areas.
â€œThe provisional settlement cements that trend and severely undermines any notions of levelling up. The final settlement, expected in early February, must be used to provide additional funding for the most in-need places.â€
Announcing the settlement, Levelling Up Secretary Michael Gove said: â€œWe recognise councils are facing challenges and that is why we have announced a Â£64 billion funding package â€“ a real-terms increase at an average of 6.5% â€“ to ensure they can continue making a difference alongside our combined efforts to level up.â€
A spokesperson for the Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities said: â€œThe 2024/25 settlement will also see the most relatively deprived areas of England receive 18% more per home than the least deprived areas.â€

Title: Storm Jocelyn: High winds force York Shambles to close
Author: By Dylan Connell @dylanconnell_ Reporter
Content:
Part of aÂ famous York street has been forced to close due to strong winds during Storm Jocelyn.
Shambles closed this morning (Wednesday, January 24) at about 10am.
The closure was put in place after tiles were blown off roofs in the historic street.
Part of Shambles closed as Storm Jocelyn hits   (Image: Dylan Connell)
Shoppers and traders were told to leave the street.
By 11.30am some business at the Kingâ€™s Square end of ShamblesÂ had reopened.
A section of the street from the York Ghost Merchants to Pavement remained closed with workers on the scene.
One shop employeeÂ told The Press that most traders had goneÂ home for the day.
Part of Shambles closed as Storm Jocelyn hits   (Image: Dylan Connell)
Tourists continued to gather at either end of Shambles taking photographs of the historic buildings which date back to the 14th century.
James Gilchrist, director of transport, environment and planning at City of York Council, said the closure was put in place to keep the public safe.
"We were advised that there was a risk of further tiles falling given the high winds, so the decision to close the road was taken to protect the public from immediate danger," he said.
"The street remains cordoned off due to the high winds. Contractors will be visiting tomorrow to assess the situation so the road can be opened as soon as possible.
